Finite State

Detailed Description

A finite state automaton is :
  • One value per node.
  • Last value for each new sequence is a terminal state.
  • Randomly, oldest first, nodes with same value are crossing-over, lonely node for a given value are killed, until the population is collapsed under the defined threshold.
  • Terminal states increase the probability of playback head's jump.

Function Documentation

PIZFiniteState* pizFiniteStateNew ( long  argc,
long *  argv 
)

Create the automaton.

The function accept one argument : the threshold to start crossing-over. Minimum is 1, maximum is 100, default is 35. In case of failure the pointer is NULL.

Parameters:
argc The number of arguments.
argv A pointer to arguments.
Returns:
A pointer to the new automaton.
Remarks:
The following shows how to create an automaton. 
 long args = 50;

 PIZFiniteState *fsa = pizFiniteStateNew (1, &args);
 PIZFiniteState *fsa = pizFiniteStateNew (0, NULL); // default value

long  argc,

)

Add values to the automaton.

Parameters:
x A valid pointer.
argc The number of values.
argv A pointer to the values.
Returns:
An error code.
Remarks:
The number of nodes can not be more than 128 at a given time, exceedings ones will be ignored.

Definition at line 218 of file pizFiniteState.c.

PIZError pizFiniteStateProceed ( PIZFiniteState *  x,
long  argc,
long *  argv 
)

Fill a given array with automaton values.

Remarks:
Each step the playback head randomly moves in the automaton. It does not reverse. At the end of a branch, it jumps. Each step, chances to jump increase (terminal states raise it more).
Parameters:
argc Number of step to proceed.
argv Pointer to the array.
Returns:
An error code.
